title: Side Hustle Tax Guide: How Much to Set Aside
excerpt: Side income means self-employment taxes. Learn exactly how much to save and avoid a surprise tax bill that wipes out your earnings.
relatedKeywords: how much to save for taxes
content:
## The Side Hustle Tax Reality

Side income feels like bonus money. Until April.

Unlike your regular job where taxes are automatically withheld, side hustle income arrives untaxed. The IRS still wants their share. Without proper planning, your side hustle can result in:

- Unexpected tax bill
- Penalties for not paying quarterly
- Feeling like you worked for free

This guide ensures that does not happen.

## Understanding Self-Employment Tax

### What Makes It Different

Employees pay 7.65% for Social Security and Medicare. Their employer pays another 7.65%.

Self-employed people pay both halves: 15.3% total.

**Self-employment tax breakdown:**
- Social Security: 12.4% (on first ~$160,000)
- Medicare: 2.9%
- **Total: 15.3%**

This is in addition to regular income tax.

### Total Tax Obligation

**Self-employment tax:** 15.3%
**Plus income tax:** 10-37% (depends on total income)

**Combined:** Often 25-35% of net self-employment income.

## How Much to Set Aside

### The Simple Rule

**Set aside 25-30% of every side hustle payment immediately.**

This is not optional. This is not saving. This is money you owe.

### More Precise Calculation

**Lower bracket (income under $40,000 combined):**
- 20-25% set aside

**Middle bracket ($40,000-$85,000):**
- 25-30% set aside

**Higher bracket (over $85,000):**
- 30-35% set aside

### Example

**Side hustle earnings:** $500/month
**Tax set-aside (30%):** $150/month
**Your actual earnings:** $350/month

The $500 is gross. The $350 is what you actually get to spend.

## The Tax Savings System

### Step 1: Open a Separate Account

Open a savings account exclusively for taxes. Name it "Taxes - Do Not Touch."

### Step 2: Transfer Immediately

When side hustle payment arrives:
1. Calculate 25-30%
2. Transfer to tax account immediately
3. Remaining goes to regular checking

**Automate if possible.** Some banks allow automatic percentage transfers.

### Step 3: Do Not Touch It

This money is not yours. It belongs to the IRS. Do not use it for anything else.

### Step 4: Pay Quarterly Taxes

If you owe more than $1,000 in taxes for the year, you need to pay quarterly estimated taxes.

**Quarterly due dates:**
- Q1: April 15
- Q2: June 15
- Q3: September 15
- Q4: January 15

**How to pay:** IRS Direct Pay or payment voucher (Form 1040-ES).

## What Expenses Can You Deduct?

### Reduce Your Tax Bill

Deductible expenses reduce your taxable income.

**Common side hustle deductions:**
- Supplies and materials
- Equipment used for work
- Home office (if dedicated space)
- Mileage for work-related driving
- Phone and internet (portion used for work)
- Software and subscriptions for work
- Professional development
- Advertising and marketing

### Mileage Deduction

If you drive for your side hustle:
- Standard mileage rate: $0.67/mile (2024)
- Track every work mile

**Example:** 500 miles/month = $335 deduction

### Home Office Deduction

If you have dedicated space:
- Calculate square footage percentage
- Deduct that percentage of rent/mortgage, utilities, insurance

**Example:** 100 sq ft office in 1,000 sq ft apartment = 10% deduction.

## Tracking for Tax Time

### What to Track

**Income:**
- Date received
- Source (client/platform)
- Amount

**Expenses:**
- Date
- What/description
- Amount
- Business purpose

**Mileage:**
- Date
- Destination and purpose
- Miles driven

### Tools to Use

**[Pennywise](https://apps.apple.com/si/app/pennywise-finance-tracker/id6754343519):** Track side hustle income and expenses.

**Mileage app:** Stride, MileIQ, or simple spreadsheet.

**Keep receipts:** Digital photos are fine.

## Common Side Hustle Scenarios

### Freelancing/Consulting

**Income:** Invoiced to clients
**Tax forms:** You will receive 1099-NEC if paid $600+ by any single client
**Deductions:** Home office, equipment, software, professional development

### Gig Economy (Uber, DoorDash)

**Income:** Platform payments
**Tax forms:** 1099-K from platforms
**Deductions:** Mileage (biggest one), phone, supplies

### Selling Online (Etsy, eBay)

**Income:** Sales minus platform fees
**Tax forms:** 1099-K if over threshold
**Deductions:** Materials, shipping, home office, advertising

### Rental Income

**Income:** Rent collected
**Tax forms:** Different from self-employment
**Deductions:** Mortgage interest, repairs, depreciation, insurance

## What If You Did Not Set Aside Enough?

### Tax Time Surprise

If April arrives and you owe more than expected:

**Options:**
- Pay from savings (if available)
- IRS payment plan (installment agreement)
- Credit card (high interest, last resort)

**Going forward:** Increase your set-aside percentage.

### Penalties

**Underpayment penalty:** If you owe over $1,000 and did not pay quarterly.

**How to avoid:** Pay 90% of current year tax or 100% of prior year tax through withholding and estimated payments.

## Special Situations

### Side Hustle Plus Regular Job

You can increase W-4 withholding at your regular job to cover side hustle taxes.

**Advantages:**
- No quarterly payments needed
- Simpler management

**How:** Adjust W-4 to withhold additional amount per paycheck.

### Losses in Your Side Business

If expenses exceed income, you may be able to deduct losses against other income.

**Caution:** IRS requires profit motive. Losses year after year raise red flags.

### Multiple Side Hustles

Track each separately but combine for total self-employment tax calculation.

## Year-End Checklist

**Before December 31:**
- [ ] Total up all side hustle income
- [ ] Gather all expense receipts
- [ ] Calculate total mileage
- [ ] Ensure Q4 estimated payment is made (due Jan 15)

**For tax filing:**
- [ ] 1099s from all payers
- [ ] Expense summary by category
- [ ] Mileage log
- [ ] Home office calculation (if applicable)

## The Math That Matters

### Quick Calculation

**Gross side hustle income:** $10,000
**Deductible expenses:** $2,000
**Net self-employment income:** $8,000

**Self-employment tax (15.3%):** $1,224
**Income tax (assume 22%):** $1,760
**Total tax owed:** ~$2,984

**Effective rate:** ~30% of gross

This is why 25-30% set-aside works.

## The Bottom Line

Side hustle income is real income with real tax obligations.

1. Set aside 25-30% of every payment immediately
2. Keep that money untouchable
3. Track all expenses and mileage
4. Pay quarterly if required
5. Claim legitimate deductions

Do this right, and your side hustle becomes actual extra money instead of a tax-time headache.
